description: From Middle English veir, veire, from Old French vair, veir, from the accusative singular masculine form of Latin varius (“variegated”).

entries.meaning: (archaic) A type of fur from a squirrel with a grey back and white belly, much used on garments in the Middle Ages.
examples: Bran wore grey breeches and white doublet, his sleeves and collar trimmed with vair.

entries.meaning: (heraldry) An heraldic fur formed by a regular tessellation of bell shapes in two colours, (for example in the image, blue and white).
